questions.text:
Sequentially arrange the following fundoscopic findings according to the respective grades in which they are seen, as per Keith Wagener Barker (KWB) grading of hypertensive retinopathy, starting with grade 1.
  1. Macular star
  2. Optic Disc swelling
  3. Retinal arteriolar narrowing 
  4. Arteriovenous nipping
questions.solution:
The correct sequence according Keith Wagener Barker (KWB) grading of hypertensive retinopathy is

3. Retinal arteriolar narrowing 

4. Arteriovenous nipping

1. Macular star

2. Optic Disc swelling

Keith Wagener Barker (KWB) grading of hypertensive retinopathy:

Grade 1: Presence of mild generalized retinal arteriolar narrowing. 

Grade 2: Presence of focal arteriolar narrowing and arteriovenous nipping.

  • Copper wiring: Opacified appearance of arteriolar walls.
  • Salus’s sign: Deflection of retinal vein as it crosses the arteriole.
  • Gunn’s sign: Tapering of the retinal vein on either side of the AV crossing.
  • Bonnet’s sign: Banking of the retinal vein distal to the AV crossing.

Grade 3: Grade 2 plus retinal hemorrhages, exudates and macular star.

  • Retinal hemorrhages:
    • Dot-blot hemorrhages: Bleeding in the inner retinal layer
    • Flame shaped hemorrhage: Bleeding is in the superficial retinal layer
  • Retinal exudates:
    • Hard exudates: Lipid deposits in the retina
    • Soft exudates: These are also known as cotton wool spots which appear due to ischemia of the nerve fibers
  • Macular Changes
    • Macular star formation due to deposition of hard exudates around the macula.

Grade 4: Severe grade 3 plus optic disc swelling. This is a marker of malignant hypertension.

questions.text: A diabetic patient with foci of infection was diagnosed with SIRS. Which of the following is not included under the criteria for SIRS(Systemic inflammatory response syndrome)?

choices.text: Tachypnoea
Hypothermia
Bradycardia
>10% band forms on peripheral smear

questions.solution:
Bradycardia is not a part of SIRS criteria. 

SIRS is diagnosed when two of the following are present:

  • Hyperthermia (>38 Degree Celcius) or Hypothermia (<36 Degree Celcius)
  • Tachypnoea (>20/min) or arterial carbon dioxide tension (PaCO2) of less than 32 mm Hg
  • Tachycardia (>90/min) 
  • White cell count >12 x 109/litre or <4 x 109/litre or >10% Band forms

Sepsis is SIRS with a documented infection.

questions.text:
Sequentially arrange the following structure as per their contribution to the formation of corresponding parts of Inferior Vena Cava from superior to inferior:

 

  1. Right Supra cardinal vein
  2. Right Vitelline vein
  3. Right Subcardinal vein
  4. Right Posterior Cardinal Vein
questions.solution:
The correct sequence is 

2. Right vitelline vein
3. Right subcardinal vein
1. Right Supra cardinal vein
4. Right Posterior Cardinal Vein

 

The veins contributing to the formation of IVC from upwards to below are as follows:

  1. Cardiac termination of the right vitelline vein, also known as the right hepatocardiac channel
  2. Anastomosis between right vitelline and right subcardinal veins (Hepatic segment of IVC)
  3. Right subcardinal vein (Subcardinal or Pre-renal segment of IVC)
  4. Anastomosis between right supra cardinal and right subcardinal veins (Renal segment of IVC)
  5. Part of the right supra cardinal vein (Supracardinal or Post-renal segment of IVC)
  6. Anastomosis between right supra cardinal and right posterior cardinal veins
  7. Part of the right posterior cardinal vein
  8. Common iliac veins

questions.text:
Mark the following statements as true or false:
  1. Before puberty, the cervix to corpus ratio is 2:1 while it reverses at puberty
  2. Cervix to corpus ratio may raise up to 1:3 or 1:4 during reproductive years
  3. NaCl content in the cervical mucous decreases at ovulation
  4. Cervical epithelium shows no periodic alteration during the menstrual cycle
  5. The decidual reaction of pregnancy is seen only rarely in the cervix
questions.solution:
• Before puberty, the cervix to corpus ratio is 2:1 while it reverses at puberty - True
  • Cervix to corpus ratio may raise up to 1:3 or 1:4 during reproductive years - True
  • NaCl content in the cervical mucous decreases at ovulation - False
  • Cervical epithelium shows no periodic alteration during the menstrual cycle - True
  • The decidual reaction of pregnancy is seen only rarely in the cervix - True

 

The relationship between the length of the cervix and that of the body of the uterus varies with age.

Age Cervix/Corpus ratio
Before puberty

2:1
At puberty

1:2
Reproductive age 1:3 or 1:4
After menopause The whole of uterus and cervix atrophy and the portion vaginalis may disappear eventually.

 

The sodium chloride content in the cervical mucous increases (not decreases) at ovulation. It forms a fern-like pattern when a drop of the mucous is dried on a slide and studied under the microscope.

The cervix is in marked contrast to the body of the uterus both structurally and functionally. The Cervical epithelium shows no periodic alteration during the menstrual cycle, unlike the body of the uterus. In fact, even with regard to conception, the decidual reaction of pregnancy is seen only rarely in the cervix.

questions.text:
Mark the following statement true or false with respect to monozygotic twins:
  1. Monozygotic twins are more common than dizygotic twins
  2. Division within 72 hours causes the formation of 2 separate placentae, chorion and amnion
  3. Division after the formation of inner cell mass causes the formation of diamniotic monochorionic twins
  4. Division after 8 days of fertilization would result in a monochorionic monoamniotic twin
  5. Division occurring after 10 days of the fertilisation results in the formation of conjoined twins
questions.solution:
• Monozygotic twins are more common than dizygotic twins - False
  • Division within 72 hours causes the formation of 2 separate placentae, chorion and amnion - True
  • Division after the formation of inner cell mass causes the formation of diamniotic monochorionic twins - True
  • Division after 8 days of fertilization would result in a monochorionic monoamniotic twin - True
  • Division occurring after 10 days of fertilisation results in the formation of conjoined twins - False

 

Dizygotic twins (80%) are more common than monozygotic twins (20%)

 

  • Division prior to the morula stage, i.e, within 72 hours, results in two separate placenta, chorions, and amnions. This is called as diamniotic-dichorionic or DCDA - 30%.
  • Division after the formation of the inner cell mass when the chorion as already developed, between the 4th and the 8th day, results in the formation of monochorionic diamniotic twins MCDA - 70-75%
  • Division after the eighth day of fertilization, when the amniotic cavity has already formed, results in the development of a monoamniotic-monochorionic twin develops - MCMA 1-2%.
  • Division occurring after 12 days of fertilization results in the formation of a conjoined twin - <1%

questions.text: Consider the following statements regarding Screening Tests and mark True or False:
questions.solution:
• Screening tests are indeed applied upon healthy Population
  • Screening tests are to be applied only for diseases that are an important health problem in the population and have an effective treatment available.
  • Screening tests cannot be used as a basis for treatment and need a diagnostic test to be performed for confirmation of the diagnosis
  • The initiative for a screening test comes from the investigator for a screening test as the test is generally applied upon apparently healthy individuals who do not have complaints.
  • The most common neonatal disease screened is neonatal hypothyroidism and the sample for that is indeed umbilical cord blood.

Screening tests are done on apparently healthy individuals, the results of the test are relatively inaccurate, the tests are based on one criterion.

Features of a screening test:

Done On Apparently healthy
Applied On Groups, Population
Test Results Arbitrary, Final
Based On One Criterion ( Cut off )
Cost Relatively Cheaper
Time Taken Relatively Rapid
Accuracy Relatively Inaccurate
Basis for treatment   Can't be used as the basis
Initiative from Investigator

Screening tests for a condition are recommended in the following conditions:

  • Early diagnosis can change the disease course.
  • The disease should have an asymptomatic stage.
  • The disease should have a test for the diagnosis and treatment of the disease.
  • The natural history of the disease should be well known.

questions.text: match

Theme and focus: Jaundice

Lead in question: For each of the following case scenarios, pick the appropriate cause of jaundice from the above answer option list.

  1. Cholestatic jaundice
  2. Hepatitis A
  3. Criggler najjar syndrome
  4. Hemolytic jaundice
  5. Gilbert’s syndrome
  6. Chronic hepatitis
  7. Hepatitis B
  8. Primary biliary cholangitis
questions.solution:
Case 1: Elevated levels of unconjugated bilirubin which are further increased after a 48-hrs of fasting is diagnostic of Gilbert’s syndrome. It is an inherited metabolic disorder resulting in increased unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. The disease occurs due to a decrease in uridine diphosphate (UDP) glucuronyl transferase. Patients usually have episodes of jaundice that are triggered by stress such as acute illness, fasting, or exercise. The condition does not require treatment.

 

Case 2: The clinical features and the presence of high levels of alkaline phosphatase and bilirubin, and antimitochondrial antibodies are all suggestive of primary biliary cholangitis. It is a progressive non-suppurative cholangiohepatitis, with the destruction of small interlobular bile ducts. The term “primary biliary cholangitis” has replaced “primary biliary cirrhosis” because many patients do not have cirrhosis. The disease is common in women aged 40-60 years.

The patients present with fatigue, pruritus. Examination reveals hepatosplenomegaly. In late stages, jaundice, steatorrhoea and portal hypertension findings may be seen.

Laboratory findings reveal normal blood counts, elevated alkaline phosphatase, cholesterol (especially HDL), and bilirubin. Antimitochondrial antibodies are present in 95% of patients, and serum IgM levels are elevated.

 

Related Pearl: Types of Jaundice

Type of jaundice Serum bilirubin Urine Urobilinogen Urine bilirubin
Pre-hepatic ↑ Indirect          ↑        -
Hepatic ↑ Direct and indirect   Normal/ ↓       +/-
Post-hepatic ↑ Direct          -        +

questions.text:
Theme - Triage Lead in question - You have been deployed to a region of natural calamity with mass casualty as part of Disaster Management team and are required to Triage the Patients in the field for determining the order of treatment priority. Choose appropriate colour tag and the corresponding priority hierarchy.
  1. Red, Medium priority
  2. Yellow, Least priority
  3. Black, Low priority
  4. Green, High priority
  5. Red, High priority
  6. Yellow, Medium priority
  7. Black, Least priority
  8. Green,  Low priority
questions.solution:
Scenario 1:

The 27 years old man with an isolated humerus fracture and no other injuries with stable vitals would be classified as yellow, medium priority. Isolated long bone fractures in an otherwise stable are classified as medium priority injuries.

Scenario 2:

The 42-year-old agitated female who is unable to speak with the O2 saturation falling rapidly clearly has airway compromise. Since no other major visible external injuries are noted, immediately re-establishing the airway would be potentially life-saving for the patient. So, she is to be classified as red, high priority.

Related Pearl: Triage Colour Coding

 Triage system consists of four colour codes:

Color code Type of patients Examples
Red (High priority)

Need for immediate resuscitation or surgery in the next 6 hours or transfer.

May survive if timely medical intervention can be given
  • Tension pneumothorax
  • Airway obstruction
  • Hemothorax
  • Cardiac tamponade
  • Acute circulatory arrest
  • Major intra-abdominal bleed etc.
Yellow (Medium priority)

Possible resuscitation or surgery in the next 24 hours.

Likely to survive if prompt treatment is given.
  • Compound fractures
  • Degloving injuries
  • Pelvic fracture
  • Spinal injuries
  • Moderate head injury
Green (Low priority)

Ambulatory patients or minor illnesses.

Likely to survive if treatment is slightly delayed.
  • Simple fractures
  • Minor lacerations etc.
Black (Least priority)

Dead or moribund patients.
  • Severe brain injury
  • Major damage / disruption to chest wall and abdominal structures

questions.text:
Assertion: Dipyridamole can be used as a stress test to provoke angina pectoris.
Reason: Dipyridamole causes coronary steal phenomenon.

choices.text: Both Assertion and Reason are independently true/correct statements and the Reason is the correct explanation for the Assertion
Both Assertion and Reason are independently true/correct statements, but the Reason is not the correct explanation for the Assertion
The assertion is independently a true/correct statement, but the Reason is independently a false/incorrect statement
The assertion is independently a false/incorrect statement, but the Reason is independently a true/correct statement
Both Assertion and Reason are independently false/incorrect statements

questions.solution:
Dipyridamole can be used as a stress test to provoke angina pectoris because it causes coronary steal phenomenon.

Nonselective vasodilators like adenosine/ dipyridamole can worsen the perfusion of ischemic areas of the myocardium by dilating the relatively constricted arterioles of the healthy myocardium, thereby leading to a redistribution of blood flow away from the ischemic myocardium. This is termed as “steal phenomenon”. So, in general, dipyridamole is not preferred for treatment in patients with CAD. It is indicate for the secondary prophylaxis of stroke in a fixed-dose combination with aspirin. 

So, both assertion and reason are independently true/correct statements and the reason is the correct explanation for the assertion.

questions.text:
Mark the following statements as true or false regarding necroptosis and pyroptosis:

a. Inflammation is present in both

b. Pyroptosis is also known as programmed necrosis

c. Necroptosis is a caspase-independent programmed cell death

d. Necroptosis begins similar to the intrinsic pathway of apoptosis

e. Abortive HIV infection can lead to pyroptosis
questions.solution:
a. Inflammation is present in both - True

Both necroptosis and pyroptosis are accompanied by inflammation, as is necrosis. Only apoptosis is noninflammatory.

b. Pyroptosis is also known as programmed necrosis - False

Necroptosis, not pyroptosis, is also known as programmed necrosis

c. Necroptosis is caspase-independent programmed cell death - True

Unlike apoptosis, necroptosis does not result in caspase activation and hence it is also referred to as “caspase-independent” programmed cell death.

d. Necroptosis begins similar to the intrinsic pathway of apoptosis - False

Necroptosis begins similar to the extrinsic, not intrinsic, pathway of apoptosis, i.e. by receptor-ligand interaction. The most well studied is the TNF-TNFR mediated pathway. The pathway is as below:

e. Abortive HIV infection can lead to pyroptosis - True

Non-cytopathic (abortive) HIV infection causes pyroptosis by the activation of the inflammasome pathway. Inflammatory cytokines and cellular contents released during this process potentiate the recruitment of new cells and increase the numbers of cells that can be infected. This form of cell death may play an important role in the spread of the infection.

Pyroptosis is a process of cell death that is different from apoptosis and necrosis. It is involved in the clearance of necrotic and infected cells.

  • This type of programmed cell death is dependent on caspase 1 and caspase 11.
  • Cells infected by microbes → activation of inflammasome complex → activation of the caspase-1 → generation of biologically active IL-1 → fever, inflammation, leukocyte recruitment.
  • Caspase-1, along with caspase-11, also causes the death of infected cells.

Pyroptosis differs from apoptosis by the following features:

  • There is cellular swelling.
  • Cell membrane damage is present.
  • There is inflammation.
  • Caspase 1 and caspase 11 are involved.

questions.text:

  2. Schwalbe line
  3. The anterior surface of the iris
  4. The Anteromedial surface of the ciliary body

questions.solution:

questions.text:
Which of the following are established risk factors for postoperative pulmonary complications?
  1. Well-controlled asthma
  2. Cigarette use of >40pack years
  3. COPD
  4. Neurosurgery
  5. Abnormal PFT
questions.solution:
Surprisingly asthma which is well controlled or abnormal PFT results are not established risk factors for postoperative pulmonary complications.

Risk Factors for Postoperative Pulmonary Complications
Patient-Related
• Age ≥60 yr
• ASA-PS class ≥2
• Heart failure
• Partial or total functional dependence
• Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease
• Weight loss
• Delirium
• Cigarette smoking
• Alcohol use
• Abnormal chest examination findings

Procedure-Related
• Thoracic surgery
• Abdominal surgery
• Neurosurgery
• Head and neck surgery
• Emergency surgery
• Vascular surgery
• Use of general anesthesia
• Blood product transfusion

Laboratory Test–Related
• Albumin level <35 g/L
• Abnormal chest radiograph
• BUN level >7.5 mmol/L (>21 mg/dL)

questions.text:
Mark the following statements as true or false:
  1. Nerve injury associated with an open fracture should be explored early
  2. Nerve injury with fractures that need internal fixation can be planned for delayed exploration
  3. Fractures with concomitant vascular injury are considered indication for early exploration
  4. Nerve damage diagnosed after manipulation of the fracture should be explored early
  5. Nerve injury associated with a closed fracture should always be explored early
questions.solution:
Nerve injury associated with an open fracture should be explored early - True

Nerve injury with fractures that need internal fixation can be planned for delayed exploration - False

Fractures with concomitant vascular injury are considered an indication for early exploration - True

Nerve damage diagnosed after manipulation of the fracture should be explored early - True

Nerve injury associated with a closed fracture should always be explored early - False

 

 

 

The Indications for early exploration are:

  • Open fracture associated with the Nerve injury
  • A fracture that needs internal fixation associated with the Nerve injury
  • A vascular injury being concomitantly present
  • Diagnosis of Nerve damage after manipulation of the fracture

questions.text:
Match the following paraneoplastic condition with the most likely malignancy:
Column A Column B
Pityriasis rotunda Carcinoma Pancreas
Erythema gyratum repens Hepatocellular carcinoma
Migratory thrombophlebitis Lung cancer
Hypoglycaemia Mycosis fungoides
  Ovarian carcinoma
questions.solution:
1. Pityriasis rotunda is commonly associated with Hepatocellular carcinoma.
    • It is characterized by discrete, round, scaly, pigmented patches.

  2. Erythema gyratum repens is most frequently associated with lung cancer.
    • It is characterized by figurate erythema commonly with concentric erythematous bands forming a wood-grain appearance.

  3. Migratory thrombophlebitis, known as Trousseau's syndrome, occurs in about 10% of patients with pancreatic adenocarcinoma.
    • It is attributed to the production of platelet- aggregating factors and procoagulants from the tumour or its necrotic products. Both venous and arterial thrombi can occur. Venous thrombi can embolize to the lungs.

  4. Hypoglycemia commonly occurs with ovarian cancer.
    • In ovarian tumours, there is increased expression of GLUT1 which causes increased glucose uptake. This, in turn, causes hypoglycemia.
    • Insulin and insulin-like growth factors also play a role in causing hypoglycemia. 
  5. Mycosis fungoides is the most common form of cutaneous T cell lymphoma. The advanced stage of mycosis fungoides is characterized by generalized erythroderma and exfoliative dermatitis.

Related Pearl: Paraneoplastic Syndromes and Underlying Cancers

questions.text:
Assertion:  In pregnancy and Aortic regurgitation, Korotkoff sounds remain audible despite complete deflation of the cuff. 
Reason: In pregnancy and Aortic regurgitation, muffling (Fourth Koroktoff Sound)  is used for Diastolic Blood Pressure Measurement.

choices.text: Both Assertion and Reasons are independently true/correct statements and the Reason is the correct explanation for the Assertion
Both Assertion and Reasons are independently true/correct statements, but the Reason is not the correct explanation for the Assertion
The assertion is independently a true/correct statement, but the Reasons is independently a false/incorrect statement
The assertion is independently a false/incorrect statement, but the Reasons is independently a true/correct statement
Both Assertion and Reasons are independently false/incorrect statements

questions.solution:
In some conditions like aortic regurgitation, pregnancy, arteriovenous fistula, the Korotkoff sounds remain audible despite complete deflation of the cuff. In such situations, phase 4(muffling) must be used for the diastolic measurement.

 

So, Both Assertion and Reasons are independently true/correct statements, but the Reason is not the correct explanation for the Assertion.

questions.text:
Assertion: The cilia in the endocervical cells of the uterus are directed upwards.
Reason: The cilia help in preventing the spread of ascending infections.

choices.text: Both Assertion and Reasons are independently true/correct statements and the Reason is the correct explanation for the Assertion
Both Assertion and Reasons are independently true/correct statements, but the Reason is not the correct explanation for the Assertion
The assertion is independently a true/correct statement, but the Reasons is independently a false/incorrect statement
The assertion is independently a false/incorrect statement, but the Reasons is independently a true/correct statement
Both Assertion and Reasons are independently false/incorrect statements

questions.solution:
The cilia in the endocervical cells of the uterus are directed downwards (not upwards) and prevent ascending infection. The endocervical cells also help sieve out abnormal sperms and allow the healthy sperms to enter the uterus.

 

So, The assertion is independently a false/incorrect statement, but the Reasons is independently a true/correct statement

 

The other functions of the endocervical cells are to provide nutrition to sperms and to allow the capacitation of sperms.

questions.text:
Assertion: Cardiac hypertrophy is associated with increased atrial natriuretic factor gene expression.
Reason:  Hypertrophy is associated with a switch of contractile proteins from adult to fetal or neonatal forms.

choices.text: Both Assertion and Reason are independently true/correct statements and the Reason is the correct explanation for the Assertion
Both Assertion and Reason are independently true/correct statements, but the Reason is not the correct explanation for the Assertion
The assertion is independently a true/correct statement, but the Reason is independently a false/incorrect statement
The assertion is independently a false/incorrect statement, but the Reason is independently a true/correct statement
Both Assertion and Reason are independently false/incorrect statements

questions.solution:
An increase in the size of cells, which results in an increase in the size of the affected organ is known as Hypertrophy. Usually, hypertrophy is a result of increased production of cellular proteins but it can also be associated with a switch of contractile proteins from the adult to fetal or neonatal forms.

EX:- During muscle hypertrophy, the α isoform of myosin heavy chain is replaced by the β isoform, which has a slower, more energetically economical contraction.

In some cases, the genes that are expressed only during early development are reexpressed in hypertrophic cells, and the products of these genes participate in the cellular response to stress.

EX:- Atrial natriuretic factor is expressed in both the atrium and the ventricle in the embryonic heart, but it is down-regulated after birth normally. But the cardiac hypertrophy is associated with increased atrial natriuretic factor gene expression.

So, Both Assertion and Reason are independently true/correct statements, but the Reason is not the correct explanation for the Assertion

questions.text:
Assertion: The uterus normally lies in a position of anteversion and anteflexion.
Reason: The  posterior lip is felt as the lowest part of the cervix on vaginal examination of a retroverted uterus.

choices.text: Both Assertion and Reasons are independently true/correct statements and the Reason is the correct explanation for the Assertion
Both Assertion and Reasons are independently true/correct statements, but the Reason is not the correct explanation for the Assertion
The assertion is independently a true/correct statement, but the Reasons is independently a false/incorrect statement
The assertion is independently a false/incorrect statement, but the Reasons is independently a true/correct statement
Both Assertion and Reasons are independently false/incorrect statements

questions.solution:
The uterus normally lies in a position of anteversion and anteflexion.

In anteversion, the external os is directed downward and backward, so that on vaginal examination, the fingers find that the lowest part of the cervix is the anterior lip.

When the uterus is retroverted, the cervix is directed downward and forward, and the lowest part of the cervix is either the external os or its posterior lip.

 

Anteflexion of uterus is at the level of Internal os. 

Angle of Anteversion Angle of Anteflexion
Angle between the cervix and vagina Angle between cervix and uterus
90o 120o
(Remeber: V for version, V for vagina)

questions.text:
Assertion: Second sight phenomenon is seen in the case of cortical cataract.
Reason: In nuclear cataract, the change in the refractive index of the nucleus causes index myopia, causing near vision improvement.

choices.text: Both Assertion and Reason are independently true/correct statements and the Reason is the correct explanation for the Assertion
Both Assertion and Reason are independently true/correct statements, but the Reason is not the correct explanation for the Assertion
The assertion is independently a true/correct statement, but the Reason is independently a false/incorrect statement
The assertion is independently a false/incorrect statement, but the Reason is independently a true/correct statement
Both Assertion and Reason are independently false/incorrect statements

questions.solution:
The second sight phenomenon is seen in the case of nuclear cataract, not cortical cataract. In nuclear cataracts, the change in the refractive index of the nucleus causes index myopia, causing near vision improvement.

 

So, the assertion is independently a false/incorrect statement, but the Reason is independently a true/correct statement.

questions.text:
Assertion: Oral and Intravenous dose of Linezolid is the same.
Reason: Linezolid has 100% bioavailability.

choices.text: Both Assertion and Reasons are independently true/correct statements and the Reason is the correct explanation for the Assertion
Both Assertion and Reasons are independently true/correct statements, but the Reason is not the correct explanation for the Assertion
The assertion is independently a true/correct statement, but the Reasons is independently a false/incorrect statement
The assertion is independently a false/incorrect statement, but the Reasons is independently a true/correct statement
Both Assertion and Reasons are independently false/incorrect statements

questions.solution:
Linezolid is well absorbed orally and the bioavailability is 100%. So, intravenous and oral doses for linezolid are the same.

Hence, Both Assertion and Reason are independently true/correct statements and the reason is the correct explanation for the Assertion.

Linezolid binds to the P site of the 50s ribosomal subunit and inhibits bacterial protein synthesis. It is an oxazolidinone that is active against various resistant organisms including MRSA. Linezolid is associated with the side effects of myelosuppression(anaemia, leukopenia, pancytopenia, and thrombocytopenia) and serotonin syndrome due to monoamine oxidase(MAO) inhibition. Thrombocytopenia is the most common side effect.

questions.text:

1. Location at a site accessible to the patient
2. Location at a site not accessible to the patient
3. Presence of blisters
4. Absence of blisters
5. Presence of itching
questions.solution:
Location at a site that is accessible to the patient, the presence of blisters, and itching are features suggestive of an artificial bruise. 

Artificial bruises are caused by the application of certain irritant substances such as the juice of marking nut and roots or twigs of Plumbago rosea to simulate true bruises. However, the following features can be used to distinguish between the two entities.

Trait Artificial bruise True bruise
Site Accessible to the patient Anywhere
Color Dark brown Typical color progression over time

Margins Well defined and regular Ill-defined and irregular
Vesicles/Blisters Present Absent
Redness/Inflammation Present in the surrounding skin Present over bruise
Itching Present Absent
Ecchymosis Absent Present
Chemical tests Positive Negative

Bruises cannot be produced after 2 minutes of death. However, small bruises can be developed by violent forces even up to 3 hours after death. Antemortem bruises can be differentiated from postmortem bruises by the following features:

Features Antemortem bruise Postmortem bruise
Swelling Present Absent
Damage to epithelium Present Absent
Extravastion of blood Present Absent
Inflammation in tissues Present Absent

questions.text:
Sequentially arrange the stages of clinical presentation in trachoma as per the WHO Classification of Trachoma:
  1. Intense trachomatous inflammation
  2. Follicular trachomatous inflammation
  3. Trachomatous scarring
  4. Corneal opacity
  5. Trachomatous trichiasis
questions.solution:
The correct sequence is:

2. Follicular trachomatous inflammation
1. Intense trachomatous inflammation
3. Trachomatous scarring
5. Trachomatous trichiasis
4. Corneal opacity

Related Pearl: WHO classification of trachoma (FISTO)

WHO grading of trachoma

  • TF = trachomatous inflammation (follicular): five or more follicles (>0.5 mm) on the superior tarsal conjunctiva.
  • TI = trachomatous inflammation (intense): diffuse involvement of the tarsal conjunctiva, obscuring 50% or more of the normal deep tarsal vessels; papillae are present
  • TS = trachomatous conjunctival scarring: easily visible fibrous white tarsal bands
  • TT = trachomatous trichiasis: at least one lash touching the globe
  • CO = corneal opacity sufficient to blur details of at least part of the pupillary margin

questions.text:
Match the lymph nodes and the structures that drain to it:
Column A Column B
Para-aortic lymph nodes Prostate
External iliac lymph nodes Distal anal canal
Deep inguinal lymph nodes Superior Bladder
Internal iliac lymph nodes Glans penis
  Testis
questions.solution:
1. The para-aortic lymph nodes drain the testis. Paraaortic lymph nodes are a group of lymph nodes that lie in front of the lumbar vertebrae near the aorta. These lymph nodes receive drainage from the gastrointestinal tract and the abdominal organs. Paraaortic lymph node group is divided into three subgroups: preaortic, retroaortic, and right and left lateral aortic.

  2. The external iliac lymph nodes drain the Superior Bladder.

  3. The deep inguinal lymph nodes drain the glans penis. Deep inguinal lymph nodes lie medial to the femoral vein under the cribriform fascia. The uppermost node is in the groin, under the inguinal ligament, and is called Cloquet's node. The deep inguinal lymph nodes drain superiorly to the external iliac lymph nodes, then to the pelvic lymph nodes and on to the paraaortic lymph nodes.

  4. Internal iliac lymph nodes drain the prostate. The internal iliac lymph nodes (or hypogastric) surround the internal iliac artery and its branches (the hypogastric vessels), and receive the lymphatics corresponding to the distribution of the branches of it, i.e., they receive lymphatics from all the pelvic viscera, from the deeper parts of the perineum, including the membranous and cavernous portions of the urethra, and from the buttock and back of the thigh.

Related Pearl: Lymphatic drainage of pelvic structures

LYMPH NODES STRUCTURES DRAINING

External iliac lymph nodes Uterine body, cervix, superior bladder
Internal iliac lymph nodes Prostate, cervix, corpus cavernosum,proximal vagina
Superficial inguinal lymph nodes Distal vagina, vulva, scrotum, distal anal canal
Deep inguinal lymph nodes Glans penis

 

*Ref - Snells Clinical Anatomy - 4e

questions.text:
Which of the following come under major criteria for the High-risk population but not for the low-risk populations according to the revised jones criteria?

1. Monoarthritis
2. Subclinical carditis
3. Polyarthralgia
4. Fever>38.5 Degree Celcius
5. Fever> 38 Degree Celcius
questions.solution:
Polyarthralgia and monoarthritis come under the major criteria for high-risk populations, but not for the low-risk population, where only polyarthritis is considered.

Fever>38 degree celsius is a minor criteria for high-risk populations, while, 38.5 is the cutoff in a low-risk population.

Subclinical carditis and polyarthralgia are major criteria in both.

 

Note:

Populations with ARF incidence ≤2 per 100,000 school-age children or all-age rheumatic heart disease prevalence of ≤1 per 1000 population per year are considered as low risk.

Related Pearl: Revised Jones criteria for diagnosis of Acute Rheumatic Fever (ARF)

Revised Jones criteria for the diagnosis of rheumatic fever are as follows:

Major criteria
Low-risk populations* Moderate- and high-risk populations*
   
Carditis- Clinical or subclinical Carditis- Clinical or subclinical
Arthritis- Polyarthritis only Arthritis- Polyarthritis/polyarthralgia/monoarthritis
Chorea Chorea
Erythema marginatum Erythema marginatum
Subcutaneous nodules Subcutaneous nodules
   
Minor criteria 
Polyarthralgia Monoarthralgia
Fever (≥38.5°C) Fever (≥38°C)
ESR ≥60 mm in the first hour and/or CRP ≥3.0 mg/dL ESR ≥30 mm/hr and/or CRP ≥3.0 mg/dL
Prolonged PR interval, after accounting for age variability (unless carditis is a major criterion) Prolonged PR interval, after accounting for age variability (unless carditis is a major criterion) 
   
For all patient populations with evidence of preceding Group A Streptococcal infection:(Increased ASLO/ anti-DNAse B titer or positive throat culture for group A streptococcus or positive rapid streptococcal carbohydrate antigen test) 
Diagnosis of initial ARF 2 Major criteria or 1 major plus 2 minor criteria
Diagnosis of recurrent ARF 2 Major or 1 major and 2 minor or 3 minor criteria

*Low-risk populations are those with ARF incidence ≤2 per 100 000 school-aged children or all-age rheumatic heart disease prevalence of ≤1 per 1000 population per year. If the incidence exceeds the given limit, then it is moderate-high risk populations.

questions.text:
Which of the following are functions of ASHA? (Choose the most appropriate option)

 

  1. Provide DOTS under RNTCP
  2. Provide ORS for Diarrhea
  5. Counsel women about breastfeeding and complementary feeding
questions.solution:
Roles and responsibilities of ASHA:
 
A. Health education:  The ASHA provides information and awareness to the community regarding nutrition, basic sanitation and hygienic practices, healthy living and working conditions, and timely utilization of health and family welfare services.
 
 
B. Maternal and child health:
  1. Facilitate utilization of health services such as immunization, antenatal and postnatal checkup and supplementary nutrition, sanitation, and other services provided by the government.
  2. Provide counseling to women on birth preparedness, safe delivery, breastfeeding and complementary feeding, immunization, contraception, and prevention of common infections.
  3. Escort/accompany pregnant women and children requiring treatment or admission to the nearest health center.
  4. Upon graded training, provide newborn care and management of common childhood illnesses.
 
C. Primary care:
  1. Provide primary care for minor ailments like diarrhea and fever and provide first aid for injuries.
  2. Provide DOTS under RNTCP.
  3. Depot holder of essential provisions such as oral rehydration therapy, iron, and folic acid tablets, chloroquine, disposable delivery kits, oral pills, condoms, etc.
 
D. Sanitation:
  1. Work with the village health and sanitation committee to create a comprehensive village health plan.
  2. Promote the construction of household toilets under total sanitation campaign
 
E. Notification: ASHA will inform births, deaths, and any disease outbreaks to the sub-center or PHC.

questions.text:
Which of the following can manifest itself as true central cyanosis? (Mark the most appropriate option)
  1. Reduced Hb > 4g/dl
  2. Reduced Hb > 30% of total Hb
  3. Methemoglobin > 1.5 gm/dl
  4. Sulfhemoglobin > 0.5gm/dl
  5. Carboxyhemoglobinaemia
questions.solution:
Carboxyhemoglobin is cherry red in color and masks the development of cyanosis usually associated with poor O2 delivery to tissues. So, carboxyhemoglobinemia does not result in true central cyanosis.

Cyanosis becomes apparent when the concentration of reduced (deoxygenated) hemoglobin in capillary blood exceeds 4 gm/dL or reduced Hb > 30% of total Hb.

Cyanosis is detectable with methemoglobin ≥ 1.5 gm% and/or sulfhemoglobin ≥ 0.5 gm%.

Cyanosis refers to the bluish color of the skin and mucous membranes, resulting from an increased quantity of reduced hemoglobin or of hemoglobin derivatives (methemoglobin or sulfhemoglobin).
It is usually most marked in the lips, nail beds, ears, and malar eminences.

The types of cyanosis are:

Central cyanosis Peripheral cyanosis

Due to diminished arterial oxygen saturation/presence of abnormal hemoglobin derivative.

Due to diminished peripheral blood flow.

Mucous membranes and skin are both affected

 Mucous membranes of the oral cavity or those beneath the tongue are spared.

Decreases after O2 supplementation

 Does not decrease after O2 supplementation

questions.solution:
The marked muscle is the pectoralis major.

It is supplied through the medial (C8, T1) and lateral pectoral nerves (C5,6,7). Fibers for the clavicular part are from C5 and 6 and the sternocostal part are from C7, 8 and T1.

It is attached to the lateral lip of the intertubercular sulcus. 

The pectoralis major has its origin from multiple sites as follows:

  • Sternal half of the clavicle
  • Anterior surface of the sternum
  • First to seventh costal cartilages
  • External oblique aponeurosis

Blood supply:

  • Pectoral branch of the thoracoacromial axis
  • Internal thoracic artery
  • Superior and lateral thoracic artery

Innervation: Medial and lateral pectoral nerves

Action: Adduction and medial rotation of the arm

5. Metastases
questions.solution:
All of the above conditions may present in the form of multiple bony lesions in a patient.

■ Infection

■ Hyperparathyroidism

questions.text:
Mark the following statements true or false regarding cerebellar cortex:

1. Dendrites of one Purkinje cell makes synaptic contact with up to 10 climbing fibers while each climbing fiber stimulates only one Purkinje cell.

2. Each mossy fiber stimulates thousands of Purkinje cells through Golgi cells

3. Granule cells are the only excitatory cells in the cerebellar cortex

4. The axons of Golgi cells, stellate cells, and basket cells inhibit the Purkinje cells

5. Lugaro cells inhibit Golgi cells
questions.solution:
All of the above statements are false.

1. Dendrites of one Purkinje cell makes synaptic contact with up to 10 climbing fibers while each climbing fiber stimulates only one Purkinje cell - False

The climbing fibers are the terminal fibers of the olivocerebellar tracts. These fibers ascend through the layers of the cerebellar cortex and terminate in the molecular layer and divide repeatedly. The dendrites of one Purkinje cell has a synaptic connection with only one climbing fiber, while each climbing fiber synapses with dendrites of 1 to 10 Purkinje cells.

 

2. Each mossy fiber stimulates thousands of Purkinje cells through Golgi cells - False

Each mossy fiber stimulates thousands of Purkinje cells through the granule cells (not Golgi cells).

 

3. Granule cells are the only excitatory cells in the cerebellar cortex - False

  • Granule cells and unipolar brush cells are excitatory while all other cells in the cerebellar cortex are inhibitory in nature.
  • The axons of the granule cells (called parallel fibers) cause excitation of thousands of Purkinje cells, and also stimulates the stellate and basket cells present in the molecular layer; and Golgi cells present in the granular layer.
  • The unipolar brush cells are also present in the granular layer. They receive excitatory input from the mossy fiber and stimulates the adjacent granule cells.

 

4. The axons of Golgi cells, stellate cells, and basket cells inhibit the Purkinje cells - False

  • The stellate and basket cells inhibit the Purkinje cells, while the Golgi cells inhibit the granular cells.

 

5. Lugaro cells inhibit Golgi cells - False

  • The Lugaro cells are cigar-shaped neurons lying at the level of Purkinje cells. They inhibit the stellate, basket and Purkinje cells.

Related Pearl: Cerebellar Circuitry

Cerebellar circuitry includes:

Afferents- Climbing and mossy fibers

  • Climbing fibers -
    • Origin - contralateral inferior olivary nucleus in the medulla oblongata
    • Terminates on - Purkinje cell
  • Mossy fibers -
    • Origin - multiple sources in the spinal cord and brainstem
    • Terminates on - Granule cell

Intrinsic components

  • Granule cell backward inhibition - done by Golgi cells- prevent transmission from mossy fibers to the granule cells
  • Purkinje cells forward inhibition- done by stellate and basket cells

Efferents -

  • The output from the cerebellar cortex - from Purkinje cells inhibitory output to the deep cerebellar nuclei
  • The output from the cerebellum - from deep cerebellar nuclei
    • Globose, emboliform, and dentate - via superior cerebellar peduncle
    • Fastigial - via inferior cerebellar peduncle

 

Related Pearl: Cerebellar peduncles and their connections

Peduncle Afferent fibers Efferent fibers

  • Globose - emboliform-rubral pathway
  • Dentatothalamic pathway

questions.text: Mark True or False regarding Fractures shaft of femur:
questions.solution:
1.  More common in elderly - False

High-velocity injuries causing shaft of femur fractures are more common in the younger population

 

2. Easily managed with gallows traction in elderly - False

Gallows traction can be tried in children <2years. Not in the elderly.

In Gallow's traction, the legs of a child are tied to an overhead beam. The hips are kept a little raised from the bed so that the weight of the body provides counter-traction and the fracture is reduced. This is continued till sufficient callus forms.

 

3. Associated with pulmonary complications - True

Fat embolism and ARDS are known complications associated with the shaft of the femur fracture

 

4. Interlocking Intramedullary nailing is gold standard for management - True

Closed intramedullary nail with interlocking screws is the preferred treatment of most femoral shaft fractures.

questions.text: Mark True or False regarding Septic arthritis:
questions.solution:
1. Staph aureus is the most common organism in young children - True

The causative organism of bacterial arthritis:

Age group /Condition Most common Organism
Overall S. aureus
Gram-negative bacteria in young children Kingella kingae
Adolescents Neisseria gonococcus
After surgical procedure Staphylococcus aureus
Prosthetic joints Coagulase-negative Staphylococci
Sickle-cell disease Salmonella sp
Complement deficiency Neisseria gonococcus

Note: 

H. influenza arthritis predominates in children younger than 2 years of age, particularly in areas with low Hib immunization rates.

(BUT NOT THE MOST COMMON ORGANISMS)

 

2. Incision and Drainage should be done after the culture of aspirate and antibiotic for 24 hrs - False

Septic arthritis is an orthopedic emergency. If not adequately treated it can lead to the destruction of articular cartilage and lead to unfavorable sequelae.  So, treatment is initiated immediately

Septic arthritis is considered to be an orthopedic emergency for the following reasons:

  • Depletion of the ground substance of the articular cartilage begins approximately 2 days after inoculation and is caused by activation of enzymes from the acute inflammatory response, production of toxins and enzymes by bacteria, and stimulation of T lymphocytes during the delayed immune response.
  • Destruction of the articular cartilage, which results from the degradation of ground substance, is apparent 4 to 6 days after infection.
  • Complete destruction of articular cartilage occurs at approximately 4 weeks. Joint dislocation or subluxation and osteomyelitis also may occur.

 Hence, it is necessary to treat septic arthritis at the earliest.

 

3. Kocher's criteria are used to differentiate from transient synovitis - True

Kocher's criteria for septic arthritis

CriterionValue

  • Fever>38.5°
  • WBC>12000 cells/µL
  • ESR>40 mm/h
  • Weight-bearingComplete inability

The probability of septic arthritis may be as high as 99.6% when all four criteria below are present and <0.2% when none are. 

4. Widening of joint space is the long term sequelae - False

 In the initial stage, there is joint space widening from localized edema. As the infection progresses, joint space narrowing from destruction of articular cartilage may become evident. 

 The Position of the hip is Flexion, abduction & external rotation. FABER is due to the accumulation of pus in the joint. Can change to FADIR on joint destruction.

questions.text:
While reading the ECG of a patient, you notice the presence of Osborn J waves. Which of the following conditions may be seen in this patient?

1. Hypocalcemia 2. Hyperkalemia 3. Hypothermia 4. Hyperthermia 5. Hypercalcemia
questions.solution:
Osborn J wave can be seen in hypothermia and hypercalcemia.

Osborn J wave consists of an extra deflection on the ECG at the terminal junction of the QRS complex and the beginning of the ST-segment take off.

  • Results from an exaggerated outward potassium current leading to repolarization abnormality.
  • Usually, occurs when the core body temperature falls below 90 °F (32 °C), seen in conditions such as hypothermia.
  • They can also be found in other conditions such as hypercalcemia.

questions.text:
The root value of the structure marked by the red arrow in this image is:
  1. C5
  2. C6
  3. C7
  4. C8
  5. T1
questions.solution:
The marked structure is lateral to the third part of the axillary artery. Hence, it is identified as the trunk of the Median nerve. The root value is C5-8, T1.

Relations of the third part of the axillary artery: 

Anterior: Skin and fascia, the medial root of the median nerve

Posterior: Lower part of subscapularis and tendons of lattisimus dorsi and teres major, radial and axillary nerves

Lateral: Musculocutaneous nerve (for a short distance), Lateral root, and then the trunk of the median nerve

Medial: Medial cutaneous nerve of forearm, Ulnar nerve

Related Pearl: Brachial Plexus

Brachial Plexus

  • C5 to T1
  • Roots (from spinal cord) > Trunks (in the neck)> Divisions (passing behind clavicle) > Cords and Branches (in the axilla).
  • Covered by prevertebral fascia extension called "axillary sheath"

Trunks:

  • Upper trunk: C5 and C6
  • Middle trunk: C7.
  • Lower trunk: C8 and T1

Divisions:

  • Anterior divisions - Forms lateral and medial cords supplying mainly flexors 
  • Posterior divisions - Forms posterior cord which suppy mainly extensors 

Cords:

  • Lateral cord: Formed by anterior divisions of the upper and middle trunks.
  • Posterior cord: Formed by all 3 posterior divisions 
  • Medial cord: Formed by anterior division of the lower trunk.

Branches: 

 Parts 

Branches
Roots

Dorsal scapular nerve (C5)

Long thoracic nerve of Bell (C5-C7)
Upper trunk

Suprascapular nerve (C5, C6)

Nerve to Subclavius (C5, C6).
Lateral cord (LML)

Lateral root of median nerve (C5-C7)

Medial pectoral (C8,T1)

Note : However Ulnar Nerve near its origin, often receives a communicating branch from the lateral root of the median nerve originating from the lateral cord and carrying fibers from C7.

questions.text:
Match the following images with the respective instruments:

Column A

  1. Image A
  2. Image B
  3. Image C
  4. Image D

 

Column B

  1. Bone gouge
  2. Osteotome
  3. Periosteal elevator
  4. Curette
questions.solution:
The correct match is:

  • A is the periosteal elevator.
  • B is a curette used for curetting a cavity in bone or removing fibrous tissue from ends of fracture; used in enchondroma, GCT, osteomyelitis.
  • C has both sides beveled and hence it is an osteotome
  • D is bone gouge, a concave-bladed chisel used for cutting on round bone surfaces or making holes in the bone.

Related Pearl: Orthopedic Instruments

questions.text:
Mark the following statements as true or false:
  1. Obliteration of the left umbilical vein gives rise to ligamentum teres hepatis
  2. Ligamentum venosum is the fibrous remnant of ductus venosus
  3. The lateral umbilical folds contain the obliterated umbilical arteries
  4. The medial umbilical fold is a remnant of the fetal urachus
  5. Round ligament of the liver lies in the free border of the falciform ligament
questions.solution:
Obliteration of the left umbilical vein gives rise to ligamentum teres hepatis - True

 

Ligamentum venosum is the fibrous remnant of ductus venosus - True

 

The lateral umbilical folds contain the obliterated umbilical arteries - False

The medial umbilical folds contain the obliterated umbilical arteries. The lateral umbilical folds contain the inferior epigastric vessels.

 

The medial umbilical fold is a remnant of the fetal urachus - False

The median umbilical fold is a remnant of obliterated fetal urachus

 

Round ligament of the liver lies in the free border of the falciform ligament - True

Ligamentum teres hepatis is also known as the round ligament of the liver and lies in the free border of the falciform ligament

questions.text:
Which of the following conditions are inherited predominantly as autosomal dominant?
  1. Osteogenesis imperfecta
  2. Friedrich ataxia
  3. Ehler–Danlos syndrome
  4. Hereditary spherocytosis

questions.solution:
Alport syndrome is inherited predominantly as X linked dominant, while Friedrich ataxia is inherited as autosomal recessive.
